Certainly domains that I'm working in that sort of prior knowledge is absolutely critical, particularly in extrapolation so.
When you're dealing with interpolation, if you've got enough data, it probably doesn't matter what your prior is, right?
That's what Bayes theorem kind of tells us.
So when you're dealing interpolation, you're OK.
If you've got a nice stationary system and you can observe it frequently and densely, I'm not convinced your prior really matters that much practically.
But when you're dealing with extrapolation and for example, the climate debate at the moment is very much one of extrapolation.
We don't have observations in the regime that we're going to move into in the next 10 twenty 50 years.
Then this prior is going to be absolutely critical to what we do.

So emulators traditionally have been applied to relatively simple systems, so small numbers of output, small numbers of inputs, and that's done often by looking at emulating summary measures of the system.

So if you're looking at a global climate model rather than looking at the temperature over all the points on the earth surface, you look at the average temperature of the globe and you emulate the relationship between your inputs, which might be things to do with the way you parameterise clouds and other bits and bobs, and the output that you're interested in, which would be maybe average global temperature.
But increasingly, wanting to extend these things to high dimensional models so to multi output prediction.
So Chris is work is extremely interesting in that context and fits in with the trend in the emulation kind of area where people are really starting to try and look at multi output modeling.
Working with dynamic simulators, also important, that's one of my big interest, but also looking at calibration, which requires us to link these models to reality.

Not enough, so you need higher points or three point, maybe 4 point functions to actually model the relation between the different outputs.

So if you're looking at a global climate model rather than looking at the temperature over all the points on the earth surface, you look at the average temperature of the globe and you emulate the relationship between your inputs, which might be things to do with the way you parameterise clouds and other bits and bobs, and the output that you're interested in, which would be maybe average global temperature.
